block.p: Justice Department Clears AT&T Deal for MediaOne The Justice Department approved AT&T's proposed $58 billion acquisition of the MediaOne Group, giving the telephone giant control over more than a third of the nation's cable network for television, high-speed Internet access and online telephone service.

The decision requires the companies to sell their interest in Road Runner, the nation's second-largest cable Internet service. The companies now await a decision by the Federal Communications Commission, which is considering requests by competitors and consumer groups to force the sale of more assets. [Page A1.]

Shares of UAL and US Airways Fall The European Commission said that it would probably have to take a close look at the competitive aspects of United Airlines' proposed $4.3 billion takeover of US Airways. And investors focused on the challenges facing the deal, sending shares of both companies lower. US Airways slumped $4, to $45, while UAL, United's parent, fell 37.5 cents, to $52.50. [C2.]

Floor Plans With Internet Access For a growing number of home buyers, high-speed Internet connections are becoming as important as a two-car garage or fireplace, prompting some developers to jump into the telecommunications business. [A1.]

Shares in African Diamond Company An African diamond company plans to sell shares on the London Stock Exchange, offering investors a stake in a venture that includes as partners the embattled governments of Congo and Zimbabwe. [C2.]

Stocks Fall, Led Lower by Goldman Stocks slumped, led lower by financial shares after Goldman Sachs told analysts that its second-quarter profit would fall short of expectations. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 211.43 points, or 2 percent, to 10,323.92. The Nasdaq composite index fell 65.26 points, or 2 percent, to 3,205.35, erasing an earlier gain of 2.9 percent. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 17.53 points, or 1.3 percent, to 1,381.52. [C7.]

Japan to Correct Economic Data The Japanese government said it would correct its deliberate omission of data made in a report on economic growth. The new figures will show a 1.6 percent decline in gross domestic product for the October-to-December period, rather than 1.43 percent. [C4.]

Credit Card Duel at Senate Hearing Credit card company executives clashed at a Senate hearing over an antitrust lawsuit accusing Visa and MasterCard of restricting competition by barring member banks from also issuing American Express or Discover cards. Visa and MasterCard ''operate a closed, self-serving, self-perpetuating system,'' said Harvey Golub, the chairman of American Express. MasterCard's chief counsel fired back: ''If American Express gets its way, neither competition nor the consumer wins.'' [C2.]

$8 Billion Sold in TV Advertising Even after a season that saw ratings declines for most programs, executives from the six broadcast networks said they pulled in record amounts of money from advertisers in the upfront sales market, racking up a total advertising take of $8 billion. Time Warner and Disney Finish Deal Time Warner and Walt Disney completed a deal that allows the cable company to continue carrying ABC stations for six years. [C6.]
